question_text: I know TUPE applies when a business changes hands. I seem to remember reading TUPE also applies if an unrelated business takes over the premises of another business in the same sector and trades from the same location - is that correct? Example in our town. Butchers gone in to administration, staff left in limbo, talk that a new butcher will be opening in the same premises soon. Would TUPE apply in those circumstances?
bot_response: Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (TUPE) applies when there is a 'relevant transfer', which can occur when a business or part of a business moves to a new owner or merges with another business to make a brand new employer. TUPE can also apply if a service provision change occurs - for example, if a contractor takes over activities from a client, or a new contractor takes over activities from another contractor (what's often referred to as 'outsourcing' or 'in-sourcing'). The specific situation you mention involves a potential 'business transfer' under TUPE. However, the application of TUPE in such scenarios is not automatic and depends on several factors. For TUPE to apply in a business transfer, there must be a transfer of an economic entity that retains its identity post transfer. An 'economic entity' is an organised grouping of resources that has the objective of pursuing an economic activity. The mere sale of assets alone, such as a premises, would not in itself amount to a business transfer under TUPE. Based on your illustration, critical factors would be whether the new butcher firm would be taking on more than just the premises - for example, if they were taking on the same workforce, the existing customer base, or significant equipment from the old butchery. The specific circumstances of each case would determine whether TUPE applies or not. Hence, professional advice based on the precise facts is advisable in these situations.

Even if a company is dormant, you have certain responsibilities to Companies House, such as the timely filing of Confirmation Statements and accounts. I end up spending a lot of time trying to track down errors or clear up the mess their errors cause, which has been quite stressful. They have quite a turbulent personal life which exacerbates errors and often precludes discussions about finances and procedures. My discovery of the shortfall comes at a time of personal crisis for my business partner which I have every sympathy for, but I am hurt and angry that they basically took cash from the business and let me stress about our finances without telling me that they had “borrowed” the cash. I have decided I no longer trust them and no longer want to be in the partnership - but am getting severe emotional blackmail from them regarding their personal situation and their involvement in the business. My questions are really about the technicalities of how to end it - we have a fairly thorough partnership agreement of which several terms with regard to paying in, handling cash and record keeping have been broken, so it would seems I have grounds to expel them, but as a two partner partnership, presumably this would result in instant dissolution too? Dissolving the Partnership: If you believe your partner has acted in breach of your partnership agreement and you cannot see a way for the partnership to continue, you can seek to dissolve the partnership. The Partnership Act 1890 provides that where no fixed term has been agreed upon for the duration of the partnership, any partner may determine the partnership at any time, by giving notice to all the other partners. 2. If you wish to continue the business, you would have to buy out your partner's share of the goodwill. 5. Intellectual Property: Intellectual property such as the business name, logo, etc., are also assets of the partnership. Fixed Charge Creditors - These are usually lenders or banks that have a secured charge over a specific property, such as a mortgage. 2. Preferential Creditors - These are typically employees if there are any, but in your case, this category may not be applicable. 3. Floating Charge Creditors - These are usually banks / lenders with a charge over the remaining assets not covered by a fixed charge. 4. Unsecured Creditors - These include trade creditors, HMRC for VAT and PAYE, and utility companies amongst others. 5. Shareholders. Any assets or cash left in the company after repaying the creditor's should be returned to the shareholders (Directors). Based on your current scenario, it seems you fall into the category of unsecured creditors (energy, water, broadband). It is advised to distribute the remaining £600 proportionally amongst them. This should ideally be done following consultation with an insolvency practitioner who can help to ensure that the correct legal process is followed. After the company is officially dissolved, it ceases to exist and creditors won't usually be able to pursue it for unpaid debts. However, if the winding up process is not conducted properly and all creditors are not treated fairly, they could potentially apply to have the dissolution set aside or claim wrongful trading. Directors' loan accounts are typically treated as assets of the company and may need to be repaid to the company as part of the winding up process.
